section.name: Welcome to Struts
section.p: Welcome to the Struts Framework! The goal of this project is to provide an open source framework useful in building web applications with Java Servlet and JavaServer Pages (JSP) technology. Struts encourages appliation architectures based on the Model-View-Controller (MVC) design paradigm, colloquially known as Model 2 in discussions on various servlet and JSP related mailing lists.
Struts includes the following primary areas of functionality:

ul.li: A controller servlet that dispatches requests to appropriate Action classes provided by the application developer.
JSP custom tag libraries, and associated support in the controller servlet, that assists developers in creating interactive form-based applications.
Utility classes to support XML parsing, automatic population of JavaBeans properties based on the Java reflection APIs, and internationalization of prompts and messages.

section.p: Struts is part of the Jakarta Project, sponsored by the Apache Software Foundation. The official Struts home page is at http://jakarta.apache.org/struts.

section.name: Acquiring Struts
section.p:
NEW! - A milestone release, Version 0.5 of Struts has been created and made available at
http://jakarta.apache.org/builds/jakarta-struts/release/v0.5. This release will provide a stable basis for current projects being developed on Struts, while (sometimes incompatible) changes are occurring on the main code branch leading up to a Version 1.0 release later. You can track the progress towards Version 1.0, and get early warning about new features and changes, by monitoring the Release Notes that are posted on the Struts project web site, as well as included in the nightly build distributions.

section.p: Access to the CVS source repository for Struts is available through both web browser and CVS client interfaces.

In addition to the Struts distribution, you will need to ensure that you have downloaded and installed all of the prerequisite software applications. Then, follow the appropriate instructions to build Struts from the source distribution, or install and use a Struts binary distribution in your web application.

section.name: Reporting Bugs and Feature Requests
section.p:
Thanks to the gracious efforts of Nick Bauman and his employer, Cortexity, there is now an interim bug tracking system available for all of the Jakarta projects (including Struts). To report a bug, or request a feature enhancement, simply point your browser at:
http://znutar.cortexity.com. When filling out a bug report or feature request, please follow these simple rules:

ul.li:
From the list of projects and categories, select one of the following entries:
Struts / Feature Requests / New Features
Struts / Feature Requests / Enhancement
Struts / Bug Report / New Bug Report

For the Project Release field, enter the Struts version number (such as 0.5) if you are using a released version, or the date included in the filename of a nightly distribution (such as 20000922) if you are using that.

section.name: Getting Involved
section.p: There are a number of ways to get more involved in the Struts community, including contributing to the future development of Struts. Check out the following resources:

ul.li: STRUTS-USER Mailing List - Subscribe to the STRUTS-USER mailing list to communicate with other developers that are using Struts for their own applications, including questions about the installation of Struts, and the usage of particular Struts features.
STRUTS-DEV Mailing List - Subscribe to the STRUTS-DEV mailing list to communicate with other developers interested in expanding and improving the functionality supported by Struts itself.
Bug Reports and Feature Requests Use the Bug Reporting System to submit these reports.

Patches and Modules - You can contribute patches and new modules to Struts by posting them to the STRUTS-DEV mailing list. After discussion and acceptance, one of the existing Committers will add your contribution to the Struts source code base (with credit to you, of course).

Become A Committer - If you wish to contribute directly to the development of Struts, and have commit access to the CVS source repository, you can be nominated (or nominate yourself) for Committer status on this project. The rules by which committers are voted on are listed at the Jakarta web site.
